Description: THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO CONTINUE OPERATING TWO CONSTANT EFFORT BIRD BANDING STATIONS ON BLM LANDS IN WESTERN OREGON DURING THE BREEDING AND FALL MIGRATION SEASONS IN 2024 - 2028. RESULTS PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT AVIAN COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND LONG-TERM POPULATION TRENDS OF INDIVIDUAL SPECIES, PLUS ASSOCIATED DEMOGRAPHIC RATES.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00179FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: POLLINATORS AND THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THEY PROVIDE ARE VITAL TO THE RESILIENCE AND PRODUCTIVITY OF BLM LANDS, SUPPORTING ECOSYSTEM CONSERVATION, RECREATION, AND OTHER RESOURCE SUSTAINABILITY AND USAGE. POLLINATORS HAVE DIVERSE AND UNIQUE RELATIONSHIPS WITH BOTH COMMON AND RARE PLANTS, SUPPORTING THEIR REPRODUCTION, AND WITH WILDLIFE AND GAME SPECIES OF INTEREST, AS DIRECT FOOD SOURCES OR AS CORNERSTONES OF HABITAT. SECONDARY ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY POLLINATORS SUPPORT LOCAL AND GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH, INCLUDING BUILDING BIOLOGICAL AND GENETIC CAPITAL, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, AND NUTRIENT CYCLING. BLM LANDS WITH HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF POLLINATORS PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN PROVISIONING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, BOTH LOCALLY AND GLOBALLY. ENSURING THE FUTURE RESILIENCE OF THESE ECOLOGICAL SERVICES REQUIRES THAT POLLINATORS ARE SUPPORTED BY INSTITUTIONAL AND STAKEHOLDER CAPACITY AND CAPABILITY.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY IDENTIFIES 5 ACTIONS TO INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF POLLINATOR-RELATED TECHNICAL RESOURCES, IDENTIFY MANAGEMENT NEEDS FOR POLLINATORS, AND ASSIST IN THE PROACTIVE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF POLLINATOR HABITATS ON BLM LANDS. THE ACTIONS INCLUDE ADDITIONAL REVIEW AND ANALYSIS OF POLLINATOR APSI DATA, DEVELOPMENT OF 2-PAGE POLLINATOR PLANT REFERENCE GUIDES, DEVELOPMENT OF NATIVE SEED MIX GUIDANCE, DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF POLLINATOR STEWARDSHIP CERTIFICATION WORKSHOPS TO BLM STAKEHOLDERS, AND COLLABORATION WITH THE NORTH AMERICAN POLLINATOR PROTECTION CAMPAIGN (NAPPC).

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00179FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: THE BLMS ASSESSMENT, INVENTORY, AND MONITORING (AIM) PROGRAM REPRESENTS A MAJOR GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT TO CHARACTERIZE AND MONITOR VEGETATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS ACROSS BLM-MANAGED LANDS. PERHAPS THE LARGEST OPPORTUNITY TO LEVERAGE THIS INVESTMENT IS TO ADD A WILDLIFE OCCURRENCE DIMENSION TO THE AIM PROTOCOL. DONE EFFICIENTLY, THIS COULD SUBSTANTIALLY EXPAND THE POTENTIAL APPLICATIONS OF AIM DATA TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION. BIRD DATA ARE TYPICALLY THE EASIEST AND MOST COST-EFFECTIVE TYPE OF WILDLIFE OCCURRENCE INFORMATION TO COLLECT AND THEY ARE OFTEN GOOD INDICATORS OF BROADER ANIMAL COMMUNITY STRUCTURE, HEALTH, TRENDS, AND RESPONSES. OUR SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO:  1.USE SOUND RECORDERS AND WILDLIFE CAMERAS TO COLLECT LAND BIRD OCCURRENCE DATA AT 125-150 AIM SITES WITHIN THE GREAT BASIN REPRESENTING A DIVERSITY OF SHRUBLAND, WOODLAND (TO THE EXTENT POSSIBLE), AND TRANSITIONAL CONDITIONS.  2.COLLECT TRADITIONAL STANDARDIZED BIRD COUNT DATA USING THE IMBCR PROTOCOL AT A SUBSET OF   50  62 OF THESE SITES AS A BASIS FOR ANALYTICALLY ASSESSING THE ABILITY OF RECORDERS AND CAMERAS TO DETECT OCCURRENCE ON A SPECIES BY SPECIES BASIS.  3.CREATE OCCURRENCE MODELS (BASED ON AIM-DERIVED COVARIATES) AND SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS (FROM GIS-DERIVED COVARIATES) USING RECORDER AND CAMERA OCCURRENCE DATA FOR AT LEAST FOUR PRIORITY BIRD SPECIES AS AN ILLUSTRATION OF THE POTENTIAL UTILITY OF THIS APPROACH. 4.INVESTIGATE THE PERFORMANCE OF INTERPOLATED AIM COVARIATES FOR DEVELOPING SPATIALLY EXPLICIT SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS.   5.PROVIDE BLM WITH A STRONG BASIS FOR DETERMINING IF AND HOW TO FORMALLY AND SUSTAINABILITY INTEGRATE LAND BIRD MONITORING INTO ITS AIM PROGRAM. 6.LIAISON WITH USFS AND BLM TO IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO INTEGRATE LAND BIRD DATA COLLECTED AT FIA AND AIM SITES, RESPECTIVELY.

THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST IN SURVEYING EXISTING KNOWN GREATER SAGE-GROUSE LEKS WHICH ARE DIFFICULT TO ACCESS DURING THE BREEDING PERIOD DUE TO ROAD CONDITIONS AND OR PRIVATE LAND ACCESS ISSUES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BE USED TO DOCUMENT NEW UNKNOWN LEKS AND IDENTIFY SAGE-GROUSE WINTER CONCERTATION AREAS. SIGNIFICANT PORTIONS OF THE PROJECT AREA ARE REMOTE AND OR DEEDED LAND, MAKING SURFACE ACCESS DIFFICULT. THEREFORE, USING AERIAL SURVEYS WILL HELP FILL LEK DATA GAPS, ALONG WITH DOCUMENTING NEW LEKS AND OR IMPORTANT WINTER CONCENTRATION AREAS WITHIN THE PRIORITY HABITAT MANAGEMENT AREAS (PHMA).

RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IS DRAMATICALLY EXPANDING ACROSS PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE UNITEDSTATES. MUCH OF THIS EXPANSION IN THE WEST WILL INVOLVE THE DEVELOPMENT OF WIND ENERGY IN HABITATSIMPORTANT FOR GREATER SAGE-GROUSE (CENTROCERCUS UROPHASIANUS: SAGE-GROUSE) AND OTHER SENSITIVE SPECIES.THE CURRENT APPROACH TO MANAGING SAGE-GROUSE WITH RESPECT TO WIND-ENERGY FACILITIES IS TO RESTRICT THEDEVELOPMENT OF THESE FACILITIES FROM PRIORITY HABITATS. THIS APPROACH TO MANAGING SAGE-GROUSE HABITATS WILLCOME UNDER INTENSE SCRUTINY AS POLITICAL AND PUBLIC PRESSURE TO INCREASE RENEWABLE ENERGY OUTPUT RISES ANDMORE INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING SITING WIND ENERGY IN SAGE-GROUSEHABITATS. WE ARE PROPOSING TO USE GREATER SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS RESIDING IN AND NEAR A PROPOSED WINDPROJECT (PROJECT) LOCATED IN THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT HIGH DESERT DISTRICT OF SOUTH-CENTRAL WYOMINGTO DEVELOP SUCH A FRAMEWORK FOR WYOMING. THE FRAMEWORK WE ARE ENVISIONING WILL INCLUDE FORECASTS OFTHE RESPONSE OF SAGE-GROUSE TO INFRASTRUCTURE ASSOCIATED WITH A WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT (FOR USE ININFORMING AVOIDANCE AND MINIMIZATION DURING DEVELOPMENT  PHASE 1 )  THE QUANTIFICATION OF MITIGATIONREQUIREMENTS (FOR USE IN INFORMING OFFSETS  PHASE 2 )  AND AN APPROACH FOR INTEGRATING CONCEPTS OF ADAPTIVEMANAGEMENT (MONITORING DATA) INTO A PROGRAM THAT BUILDS ON ITSELF TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF WIND ENERGYDEVELOPMENTS AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AT OTHER LOCATIONS THROUGH TIME (PHASE 3). OUR PROPOSAL SPECIFICALLYFOCUSES ON THE FIRST PHASE OF THIS FRAMEWORK, WHEREIN WE WILL COLLECT PRE-DEVELOPMENT DATA TO GUIDE SITINGOF WIND ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE IN THE PROJECT TO AVOID AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS TO THE LOCAL SAGE-GROUSEPOPULATION. OUR SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) USE PRE-DEVELOPMENT RESOURCE SELECTION AND DEMOGRAPHY DATAFROM SAGE-GROUSE TO DEVELOP PREDICTION MAPS OF HABITAT SUITABILITY AND QUALITY TO INFORM SITING OF WINDENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE, (2) INFORM MINIMIZATION EFFORTS BY PREDICTING THE IMPACT OF DIFFERENT DEVELOPMENTSCENARIOS ON GROUSE POPULATION GROWTH BY USING THE HABITAT PREDICTION MAPS AND THE RESPONSE OF GROUSE TODEVELOPMENT IN THE LITERATURE OR FROM DATA FROM OTHER PROJECTS, AND (3) ESTIMATE THE MITIGATION REQUIREDBASED ON THE IMPACT ON POPULATION GROWTH. OUR METHODS INCLUDE USING PREEXISTING GROUSE LOCATION ANDSURVIVAL DATA (COLLECTED FROM 20182022) FROM NEARBY GROUSE POPULATIONS AS WELL AS COLLECTING THIS SAMEINFORMATION BEFORE, DURING, AND AFTER DEVELOPMENT AT THE PROJECT. WE WILL USE THESE DATA TO CREATE MODELSTO MAP THOSE AREAS TO BE AVOIDED OR WHERE IMPACTS FROM WIND INFRASTRUCTURE CAN BE MINIMIZED. MANAGERSAND DEVELOPERS NEED MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIVE TOOLS THAT CAN DEMONSTRATE A PROJECTS ABILITY TO AVOID,MINIMIZE, AND MITIGATE UNAVOIDABLE IMPACTS. RESULTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL EXPAND OUR UNDERSTANDING OFTHE EFFECTS OF WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS, WHICH IS NECESSARY FOR INFORMEDINFRASTRUCTURE SITING. THIS RESEARCH REPRESENTS ONE OF THE BEST OPPORTUNITIES IN THE UNITED STATES TOIMMEDIATELY ADDRESS SOME OF THE UNCERTAINTY SURROUNDING WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IN SAGE-GROUSE HABITATS.A PRIMARY GOAL WITH OUR RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP AND INITIATE AN INCLUSIVE FRAMEWORK THAT DIRECTLY BENEFITSPRACTITIONERS WORKING ON THE GROUND TO EFFECTIVELY IMPLEMENT THE MITIGATION HIERARCHY FOR MAINTAINING ANDRESTORING ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY FOR SAGE-GROUSE IN REGIONS THROUGHOUT WYOMING IMPACTED BY CONTEMPORARYAND FUTURE WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. IF THE FRAMEWORK WE DEVELOP CONTINUES TO BE BUILT UPON, THOSE TASKEDWITH MANAGING SAGE-GROUSE WILL HAVE BETTER INFORMATION FOR MINIMIZING AND OFFSETTING IMPACTS TO THESPECIES THROUGH TIME IN THE FACE OF INCREASING DEVELOPMENT.

TWO DECLINING BIRD SPECIES ARE FOUND IN WYOMINGS BIGHORN BASINGREATER SAGE-GROUSE (CENTROCERCUSUROPHASIANUS) AND THE LESSER-STUDIED PINYON JAY (GYMNORHINUS CYANOCEPHALUS). SAGE-GROUSE OCCUPIESSAGEBRUSH STEPPE AND PINYON JAY OCCUPIES ADJACENT LIMBER PINE (PINUS FLEXILIS)-WESTERN JUNIPER (JUNIPERUSOCCIDENTALIS) WOODLANDS (BOONE ET AL. 2021). WHILE JAY-OCCUPIED WOODLANDS IN THE BIGHORN BASIN OFTENOCCUR ON ROCKY RIDGES AND SLOPES, HABITAT USE IS NOT WELL DOCUMENTED ACROSS ITS RANGE (BOONE ET AL. 2021),WHERE PINYON JAYS CONTRIBUTE TO PLANTING LIMBER PINE BY SEED CACHING (PESENDORFER ET AL. 2016), AND NEWGROWTH CONIFER ENCROACHMENT INTO SAGEBRUSH STEPPE DUE TO FIRE SUPPRESSION AND CLIMATE CHANGE MAYDECREASE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT AREA AND OR QUALITY (SEVERSON ET AL. 2017). BECAUSE OF WELL-DOCUMENTEDCONIFER ENCROACHMENT (MILLER ET AL. 2019) AND BENEFITS TO SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS WHEN CONIFERS AREREMOVED (OLSEN ET AL. 2021), MECHANICAL THINNING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING OF CONIFERS IN THE SAGEBRUSHSTEPPE ARE WIDELY ACCEPTED MANAGEMENT TOOLS FOR SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT (BOYD ET AL. 2017 COOK ET AL. 2017). EMERGING CONSERVATION CONCERN AROUND PINYON JAY (ROSENBERG ET AL. 2016, PARTNERSIN FLIGHT 2019) DEMANDS MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ANY POTENTIAL OVERLAP IN HABITAT USE BETWEEN SAGEGROUSEAND JAYS. REMOVAL OF CONIFERS IN SOME AREAS (E.G., ON ROCKY RIDGELINES, FOOTHILLS, AND SLOPES) MAYNOT IMPROVE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT WHILE REDUCING CRITICAL PINYON JAY HABITAT.

THE USDI BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  WYOMING STATE AND FIELD OFFICES (HEREAFTER WY-BLM) AND THE WYOMING NATURAL DIVERSITY DATABASE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING (HEREAFTER WYNDD) HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, DATA PROVISION, EXPERT CONSULTATION, AND INFORMATION TRANSFER REGARDING PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES, AND THEIR HABITATS, IN WYOMING. THIS COOPERATION HAS LED TO MORE EFFECTIVE INTEGRATION OF RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT, MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION BY WY-BLM  INCREASED TRANSPARENCY AND DEFENSIBILITY OF MANAGEMENT DECISIONS MADE BY WY-BLM  INCREASED COST-EFFICIENCY OF WORK BY WY-BLM EMPLOYEES  MORE COORDINATED CROSS-BOUNDARY MANAGEMENT BETWEEN WY-BLM AND ADJACENT LANDOWNERS  MANAGERS  AND THE ADVANCEMENT OF THE WYNDD MISSION AND THE OVERARCHING LAND GRANT MISSION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING.IMPORTANTLY, WY-BLM X WYNDD COOPERATION ALSO ADVANCES THE NATURAL RESOURCE WORK OF DOZENS OF OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND REGION. WY-BLM X WYNDD COLLABORATIONS DEVELOP INFORMATION THAT IS RECORDED IN, AND DISTRIBUTED FROM, THE WYNDD CENTRAL INFORMATION SYSTEM. IN 2022-23 ALONE,  400 ORGANIZATIONS ACCESSED THAT SYSTEM TO INFORM THEIR WORK.RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN DATA SCIENCE, INCLUDING INCREASED QUANTITIES OF AVAILABLE BIOLOGICAL DATA AS WELL AS SOPHISTICATED WEB-BASED TECHNOLOGIES ALLOWING DISTRIBUTED ACCESS TO LARGE DATABASES, HAVE PROVIDED AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENHANCE AND MODERNIZE COLLABORATIVE INFORMATION DEVELOPMENT BETWEEN WYNDD AND WY-BLM, WITH CONCOMITANT ENHANCEMENTS OF ALL OF THE ABOVE-LISTED BENEFITS. WYNDD HAS CREATED A WEB-ACCESSIBLE DATA EXPLORER PRO APPLICATION THAT PRESENTS WYNDD-MAINTAINED INFORMATION PRODUCTS IN USEFUL FORMATS TO PROFESSIONAL USERS ABLE TO ACCESS A FULL RANGE OF APPLICATION FUNCTIONS, INCLUDING PRECISELY-MAPPED SPECIES DATA, INFORMATION OVERLAYS SPECIFIC TO USER-SUBMITTED PROJECTS AREAS, AND QUICKLY DOWNLOADABLE DATA FILES.

TRACKING RESOURCES ACROSS LANDSCAPES TO GAIN ACCESS TO HIGHLY NUTRITIOUS FORAGE IS PREDICTED TO FUNDAMENTALLY UNDERPIN MOVEMENT. MOVING BEYOND THE FOCUS OF A SINGLE SEASON IS KEY TO IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RESOURCE TRACKING. WE WILL COMPARE HOW THREE DIFFERENT SPECIESMULE DEER, ELK, AND MOOSETRACK FORAGE RESOURCES ACROSS MULTIPLE SEASONS ON THE SAME LANDSCAPE. PREVIOUS RESEARCH HAS ARTICULATED THE WAYS IN WHICH MIGRATION AND SEASONAL DYNAMICS INTERACT ACROSS THE ANNUAL LIFE-HISTORY OF UNGULATES, MEDIATED BY THE LOSS AND GAIN OF FAT RESERVES. OUR RESEARCH SEEKS TO PARSE OUT THE PHENOLOGY AND CLIMATE DRIVERS OF THE SPRING AND FALL MOVEMENT OF UNGULATES, WHICH UNDERPIN THEIR ECOLOGICAL DYNAMICS ACROSS THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE. BY FOCUSING ON THE TIMING OF SEASONAL RANGE USE AND MIGRATION EVENTS, WE WILL NOT ONLY EVALUATE THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE APPROACH, BUT ALSO GAIN INSIGHTS INTO HOW WELL IT DISCRIMINATES THE SNOW TOLERANCE AND YEAR-ROUND HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF DISPARATE SPECIES.

UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING WILL WORK ON - RIPARIAN SOIL ORGANIC CARBON- DETECTING CHANGE AND DEFINING MONITORINGEFFICIENCY. RIPARIAN PROPER FUNCTIONING CONDITION ASSESSMENTS HAVE FOCUSED ON SURFACE FACTORS WITHOUT MONITORINGCRITICAL BELOW-SURFACE SOIL ORGANIC MATTER SOIL ORGANIC CARBON (SOM SOC), NOW RECOGNIZED AS FOUNDATIONAL FORSUSTAINABLE WETLANDS. THIS IS DUE TO THE IMPORTANCE OF ORGANIC-RICH SOILS FOR ACQUIRING (BY INFILTRATION) AND STORING WATER ONS, WATER STORAGE AS SUBSURFACE ICE WELL AFTER SURFACE ICE AND SNOW HAVE MELTED. THAT ORGANIC-RICH SOILS HAVE, RELATIVE TO MINERAL SOIL WITH LOW SOM SOC CONTENT, GREATER POROSITY, GREATER HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY, A WETTER SOIL COLUMN, WEAK SUCTION, AND REDUCED SUMMER WARMING DUE TO WATER CONTENT AND AN INSULATING EFFECT, ARE FACTORS THAT SUPPORT WETLAND VEGETATION. INCREASING SOM SOC LEADS TO INCREASED WATER STORAGE AND EXPANDING WETLAND HABITAT  DECREASING SOM SOC LEADS TO LESS WATER STORAGE AND HABITAT LOSS. THIS PROCESS WILL RUN CONSECUTIVELY FROM AWARD UNTIL PROJECT END DATE.
SAGE-GROUSE IR FLIGHTS

WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A SHOREBIRD SURVEY OF THE COASTAL PORTIONS OF THE NPR-A, INCLUDING THE TLSA AND PORTIONS OF THE WESTERN NPR-A BELOW 350 METERS IN ELEVATION, FOLLOWING PROTOCOLS DEVELOPED BY THE PROGRAM FOR REGIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL SHOREBIRD MONITORING (PRISM).  WE PROPOSE TO SURVEY THE TLSA AND WILLOW PROJECT AREAS IN YEARS 1 AND 2, AND WESTERN COASTAL AREAS INCLUDING THE KASEGALUK LAGOON SPECIAL AREA IN YEARS 3 AND 4.  THIS SURVEY WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST COMPARISON OF CHANGES IN SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS AND DISTRIBUTION SINCE INITIAL SURVEYS WERE CONDUCTED IN NPR-A IN 2007-8.  THESE DATA WILL SUPPORT BOTH THE RANGE-WIDE POPULATION TREND ESTIMATION GOALS OF PRISM, AND ALSO PROVIDE IMPORTANT BASELINE DATA ON SHOREBIRD STATUS, TRENDS, AND DISTRIBUTION BEFORE PLANNED OIL AND GAS INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT IN THE WILLOW PROJECT AREA OCCURS.  NEW POPULATION ESTIMATES FOR THE NPR-A WILL HELP TARGET CONSERVATION ACTIONS BOTH LOCALLY AND RANGE-WIDE IF EXISTING DECLINES ARE CONFIRMED (OR NEW ONES ARE DETECTED) FOR ONE OR MORE SHOREBIRD SPECIES.  UP TO DATE POPULATION ESTIMATES IN THE TLSA AND OTHER COASTAL AREAS OF NPR-A WILL ALLOW FOR MITIGATION MEASURES TO BE DESIGNED, IMPLEMENTED, AND ANALYZED FOR EFFECTIVENESS BY THE LAND MANAGER IN ORDER TO MITIGATE IMPACTS TO SHOREBIRDS FROM INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT OF VARIOUS KINDS.WE WILL ALSO USE AUTOMATED RECORDING UNITS TO EVALUATE A POTENTIAL NEW METHOD TO SURVEY SHOREBIRDS AND TO DETERMINE HOW ANTHROPOGENIC AND NATURAL SOUNDS CHANGE AS THE WILLOW MASTER DEVELOPMENT PLAN (WILLOW) PROJECT AREA IS DEVELOPED, PROVIDING INFORMATION ON HOW SOUNDSCAPES CHANGE AND HOW THOSE CHANGES MAY INFLUENCE ANIMALS THROUGH TIME.  AUTOMATED RECORDING UNITS (ARUS) WILL BE DEPLOYED AT A SAMPLE OF PRISM SITES ACROSS THE NPR-A TO DETERMINE IF ARUS COULD BE A COST EFFECTIVE AND LESS INVASIVE APPROACH TO SURVEYING SHOREBIRDS AS COMPARED TO PRISM RAPID SURVEYS IN THE FUTURE. USING ARUS COULD DRAMATICALLY DECREASE COSTS FOR OBTAINING DATA ON STATUS AND TRENDS OF MANY WILDLIFE SPECIES.  FINALLY, ARUS WILL BE USED TO MEASURE CHANGES IN ANTHROPOGENIC AND NATURAL SOUNDS NEAR THE PROPOSED WILLOW PROJECT AREA BETWEEN 2023-2026 AS THE AREA UNDERGOES DEVELOPMENT OF OIL AND GAS INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE PROPOSED WILLOW PROJECT.THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THREE BLM ALASKA WILDLIFE PROGRAM PRIORITY WORK AREAS THROUGH APPLICATION OF PRISM SURVEY PROTOCOLS FOR SHOREBIRDS, AND BY COLLECTION OF SOUNDSCAPE DATA THROUGH THE USE OF AUTOMATED RECORDING UNITS, INCLUDING INVENTORYING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND DISTRIBUTION, AND LEVERAGING RESOURCES THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS.  SPECIFIC BLM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THE PROJECT CAN HELP INFORM INCLUDE FUTURE IAPS, DEVELOPMENT OF PERMITS OF ALL TYPES, AND MANAGEMENT AND MITIGATION MEASURES FOCUSED ON SHOREBIRDS AND WATERFOWL.  PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM THE PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE DISSEMINATION OF DATA IMPORTANT FOR ASSESSING STATUS AND TRENDS OF DECLINING SHOREBIRD SPECIES, DATA FOR ASSESSING WHETHER MORE COST EFFECTIVE SURVEY METHODS CAN BE DEVELOPED BASED ON ARUS, AND DATA ON BASELINE ANTHROPOGENIC SOUNDSCAPES PRIOR TO AND AFTER DEVELOPMENT.
SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT IN SW IDAHO
BLM BOISE DISTRICT AERIAL SAGE-GROUSE SURVEYS

SAGEBRUSH AND BITTERBRUSH CONSERVATION PLAYS A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN HABITAT IMPROVEMENT THAT BENEFIT THE GREATERSAGE-GROUSE, A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN IDAHO. CLIMATE CHANGE HAS HASTENED THE ENCROACHMENTOF JUNIPER OR OTHER TREE SPECIES AND HAS CONTRIBUTED TO THE CONVERSION OF SAGEBRUSH STEPPE ECOSYSTEM TO JUNIPERWOODLANDS IN MANY AREAS. REDIRECTING WOODLAND TYPE VEGETATION ALLOWS FOR REINTRODUCTION OF BRUSH SPECIES INTOAREAS, INCLUDING RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF SAGEBRUSH AND BITTERBRUSH.THROUGH THIS PROJECT, PHEASANT FOREVER, INC (PFI) PROPOSES TO IMPROVE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT BY FOSTERING THEREINTRODUCTION OF BRUSH SPECIES ONTO PUBLIC LANDS WITHIN AREAS OF SOUTHERN IDAHO. PFI WILL COLLABORATE WITHMULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS TO EXECUTE FOUR ESSENTIAL COMPONENTS AIMED AT HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, INCLUDING: (1)CONTROLLING ENCROACHING CONIFERS  (2) IMPLEMENTING PRACTICES ACROSS LAND OWNERSHIPS DESIGNED TO REDUCE THERISK OF WILDFIRE AND OR INVASIVE SPECIES PROLIFERATION  (3) RESTORING AND ENHANCING MESIC MEADOW HABITATS  (4)RESTORING SHRUBS, PERENNIAL GRASSES AND OR FORBS TO RANGELANDS.

THIS PROJECT ACCELERATES THE COMPLETION OF SAGEBRUSH STEPPE RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE IDAHO FALLS DISTRICT BLM FOR SAGE GROUSE HABITAT BENEFITS. THESE COMPONENTS INCLUDE: REDUCE THE RISK OF WILDFIRE AND OR INVASIVE SPECIES PROLIFERATION, CONTROLLING ENCROACHING CONIFERS, IMPLEMENTING PRACTICES ACROSS LAND OWNERSHIPS DESIGNED TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE MESIC MEADOW HABITATS, AND RESTORING SHRUBS, PERENNIAL GRASSES AND OR FORBS TO RANGELANDS. TAKEN TOGETHER, THE BLM, PF, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS COLLABORATIVE WORK ON BLM LAND.

THROUGH THIS PROJECT, BOISE STATE UNIVERSITY (BSU) PROPOSED TO CONDUCT A SURVEY STUDY THAT WILL RIGOROUSLY TESTVARIOUS LEPORID SAMPLING TECHNIQUES TO DEVELOP PREDICTIVE MAPS OF LEPORID SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE.METRICS PRIMARY ACTIONS BSU INTENDS TO UTILIZE IN CARRYING OUT THE PROPOSED PROJECT, INCLUDES 1) PLAN AND COORDINATE AERIAL STUDIES2) VALIDATE TESTING AND DETECTION PROTOCOLS3) CONDUCT DETECTION AND ANALYSIS OF LEPORID DISTRIBUTION AND SPATIAL VEGETATION4) PREPARE AND SUBMIT MANUSCRIPT TO PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL SUMMARIZING EVALUATION RESULTS5) PRODUCT GUIDELINES FOR SAMPLING OF LEPORIDS IN SHRUB AND GRASS ECOSYSTEMS6) PRODUCE PREDICTIVE MAP SHOWING SPATIAL ABUNDANCE OF BLACK TAILED JACK RABBITS7) PRESENT RESULTS AT CONFERENCES

IDAHO HAS ONE OF THE MOST UNDERSTUDIED INSECT FAUNAS OF THE 48 CONTINENTAL STATES. UCONN PROPOSES TO CONDUCT A MODERN BIOTIC SURVEY OF LEPIDOPTERA ON BLM LAND OF THE IDAHO FALL DISTRICT THAT WILL EMPHASIZE THE ELUCIDATION OF PREVIOUSLY UNDOCUMENTED INSECT PLANT RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION RELEVANT TO THE MANAGEMENT OF INSECT BIODIVERSITY. THEIR SAMPLING EFFORTS WILL EMPHASIZE SAMPLING OF LEPIDOPTERAN POLLINATORS AND TAXA LIKELY TO BE OF CONSERVATION IMPORTANCE. WE WILL USE STATE OF THE ART TRAPPING METHODS, DNA BARCODING TO DOCUMENT SPECIES IDENTITIES, AND SHARE MANY OF THE FINDINGS ON PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE PLATFORMS (E.G., INATURALIST AND THE BARCODE OF LIFE DATA SYSTEM). IN ADDITION TO GENERATING FAUNAL LISTS FOR EACH BLM PROPERTY AND GEOREFERENCED OCCURRENCE DATA, THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE IDENTIFICATION RESOURCES, MUSEUM QUALITY VOUCHER SPECIMENS TO BE DEPOSITED IN IDAHO PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS, AND PUBLICLY AVAILABLE GENETIC DATA, ALL OF WHICH WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON BLM LANDS. A PRIMARY GOAL WILL BE TO ASSIMILATE MUCH OF THE DATA INTO A MULTIVOLUME TREATMENT OF THE CATERPILLARS OF WESTERN NORTH AMERICA. THE PROJECT WILL EDUCATE AND TRAIN TWO TO THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND ONE PH.D. STUDENT  UCONN WILL SEEK TO INVOLVE AND MENTOR UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN ALL ASPECTS OF THEIR STUDY.

PROJECT ABSTRACT NORTH AMERICAN BREEDING BIRD POPULATIONS HAVE SUFFERED SIGNIFICANT DECLINES SINCE THE 1970S,WITH 2.9 BILLION BIRDS LOST (OVER 25  OF THE TOTAL POPULATION  ROSENBERG ET AL. 2019). IN IDAHO,BLM MANAGED LANDS HOLD LARGE TRACTS OF GRASSLAND AND ARIDLAND HABITATS, AREAS WHERE BIRDPOPULATIONS HAVE SEEN LARGE DECLINES   50  AND 18  RESPECTIVELY. IN ORDER TO AID THE IDAHO BLMWITH ITS INVENTORY AND MONITORING OF BREEDING BIRDS, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE STANDARDIZED BIRDSURVEYS AS PART OF THE INTEGRATED MONITORING IN BIRD CONSERVATION REGIONS PROGRAM ACROSS ALLSTATE BLM LANDS. THESE SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ALL IDAHO BLM FIELD OFFICES AS WELL AS THECRATERS OF THE MOON NATIONAL MONUMENT AND PRESERVE AND THE MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDSOF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA EACH YEAR FROM 2023 2025. THIS WORK WILL GENERATE ROBUST,RELIABLE, AND COMPARABLE POPULATION METRICS SUCH AS DENSITY, OCCUPANCY, AND ULTIMATELY TRENDESTIMATES FOR MOST COMMON SPECIES OCCURRING ON IDAHO BLM LANDS, INCLUDING NUMEROUS BLMSENSITIVE SPECIES. THESE DATA WILL PROVIDE THE BLM WITH A VALUABLE RESOURCE TO INFORM LANDMANAGEMENT PLANS, ENERGY OR HABITAT TREATMENT PROJECTS, AND TO IDENTIFY SPECIES OF CONSERVATIONNEED. THE RESULTS MAY ALSO PROVIDE THE BLM WITH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES FORMEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT PHYLOGENETIC AND PHYLOGEOGRAPHIC ANALYSES OF AMPHIPODS IN THE GENUS HYALELLA FROM THE GREAT BASIN AND NEARBY REGIONS TO IDENTIFY CRYPTICSPECIES AND SPECIES BOUNDARIES, DESCRIBE NOVEL SPECIES, AND UNDERSTAND PATTERNS OF DISTRIBUTION THIS WILL BE DONE BY SEQUENCING ULTRACONSERVED ELEMENTS USING NEXT GENERATION DNA SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGY AND BIOINFORMATIC ANALYSES  THE GENOMIC DATA WILL BE COMBINED WITH TRADITIONAL MORPHOLOGICAL ANALYSES TO IDENTIFY UNITS OF CONSERVATION  OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE IDENTIFICATION AND DESCRIPTION OF NOVEL SPECIES, PHYLOGEOGRAPHIC AND SPATIAL ANALYSES OF SPECIESDISTRIBUTIONS, AND IDENTIFICATION OF CONSERVATION UNITS  THIS INFORMATION WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO BLM AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS IN THE FORM OF AN ANNUAL REPORT AFTER YEAR 1, A FINAL REPORT AFTERYEAR 2, PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES AND STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS, AND PUBLICATIONS INPEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS THESE RESULTS WILL ASSIST BLM AND OTHER STATE AND FEDERA LAGENCIES IN IDENTIFYING LOCATIONS WITH UNIQUE SPECIES AND EXCEPTIONAL BIODIVERSITY, SO THAT STAKEHOLDERS ARE ABLE TO PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION DECISIONS UTILIZING THE BEST SCIENCE AND DATA AVAILABLE  AS A RESULT, THIS RESEARCH WILL ADVANCE THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR PRIORITY TO DECREASERATES OF EXTINCTION AND PROTECT EXTANT BIODIVERSITY  BY IDENTIFYING UNDESCRIBED SPECIES ANDMAPPING THE RANGES OF AMPHIPODS IN NEVADA, WE WILL HELP TO PROTECT BIODIVERSITY AND SUPPORT WILDLIFE AGENCIES IN NEVADA AND OTHER STATES AS THEY PROTECT THREATENED HABITATS SUCH AS DESERT SPRINGS  BECAUSE WE WILL USE GENOMIC APPROACHES TO MEET OUR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES, WE ARE EMPLOYING THE BEST SCIENCE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE, AND OUR RESULTS WILL GENERATE THE BEST DATA AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT DECISION MAKING BY BLM AND OTHER AGENCIES

WALKER BASIN CONSERVANCY  WBC  WILL PARTNER WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  TO PROTECT CRITICAL SPRINGS AND RIPARIAN HABITAT BY EXCLUDING LIVESTOCK WHILE PROVIDING WILDLIFE SAFE ACCESS TO THE AREAS  PRELIMINARY PROJECT WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THE VICINITY OF THE EAST WALKER RIVER AND MOUNT GRANT INCLUDING AROUND SUMMIT, ABRAHAM, AND FLETCHER SPRINGS  FUTURE WORK MAY EXPAND TO INCLUDE WORK AT ADDITIONAL SPRING AND RIPARIAN SITES IN THE REGION, SUCH AS LAPON MEADOWS, BALDWIN SPRINGS, AND RATTLESNAKE SPRING  WORK WILL INCLUDE MAINTENANCE AND CONSTRUCTION OF WILDLIFE FRIENDLY EXCLUSION FENCING, INSTALLATION OF WATER PIPING AND STOCK TROUGHS, AND MONITORING OF SPRING SITES TO PRESERVE IMPORTANT WATER AND HABITAT RESOURCES FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE  WBC EXPECTS TO MAINTAIN 4,900 FT OF FENCE, CONVERT 2,640 FEET OF FENCE TO WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCE, AND INSTALL 26,400 FT OF PIPING AND 2 WATERING TROUGHS  PORTIONS OF THE PROJECT, SPECIFICALLY PIPING TO WATER TROUGHS, ARE SCALABLE DEPENDENT ON AVAILABILITY OF ANY POTENTIAL FUNDS  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT A VARIETY OF PRIORITY AND GAME SPECIES INCLUDING MULE DEER, PRONGHORN, AND BI STATE SAGE GROUSE POPULATIONS THROUGH INCREASING ACCESS TO AND PROTECTION OF CRITICAL HABITAT  THIS WILL HAVE AN ADDITIONAL BENEFIT FOR HABITAT BY DECREASING PERMITTED LIVESTOCK USAGE AROUND SPRING AREAS BY PROVIDING OFF SPRINGS STOCK WATERING SITES

BASIN AND RANGE NATIONAL MONUMENT  BARNM  IS AN AREA THAT SPANS THE TRANSITION BETWEEN THE MOJAVE DESERT AND THE SAGEBRUSH STEPPE OF THE GREAT BASIN REGION  IT IS ONE OF THE LARGEST, MOST ECOLOGICALLY DIVERSE LANDSCAPES IN THE GREAT BASIN REGION, ENCOMPASSING APPROXIMATELY 704,000 ACRES AND PROVIDING HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF ANIMAL SPECIES AND AFFORDING RESEARCHERS THE ABILITY TO CONDUCT STUDIES OVER BROAD SPATIAL SCALES  THE 2015 PRESIDENTIAL PROCLAMATION FOR BARNM STATES THAT MANY BAT SPECIES RESIDE IN THE BASIN AND RANGE AREA S CAVES AND USE ITS  LOWLANDS FOR FORAGING  HOWEVER, THERE HAVE BEEN NO BAT STUDIES CONDUCTED IN THIS AREA TO DATE  UTILIZING A ROBUST SAMPLING DESIGN, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO NOT ONLY IDENTIFY ALL BAT SPECIES USING BARNM LANDS, DURING THE 5 YEAR EFFORT, BUT ALSO OFFER SUBSTANTIAL INSIGHT INTO HABITATS USED BY BAT SPECIES AND POTENTIALLY INSIGHT INTO RECREATION IMPACTS ON BATS USING BARNM  ONCE THE DATA HAS BEEN COLLECTED AND ANALYZED, PUBLIC OUTREACH EFFORTS WILL FOLLOW, INCLUDING CREATING PRINTED EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR THE CALIENTE FIELD OFFICE OUTLINING BAT SPECIES PRESENT IN BARNM, AS WELL AS HOSTING BOOTHS AT VARIOUS PUBLIC EVENTS IN ALAMO, NV AND CALIENTE, NV SHOWCASING BARNM BAT SPECIES, THEIR NATURAL HISTORIES AND PROVIDING EFFORTS TO DISPEL MYTHS ASSOCIATED WITH BATS  THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT THE ELY DISTRICT BLM OFFICE AND NDOW, AS WELL AS THE PUBLIC DUE TO THE FACT THAT THIS PROJECT WILL ENRICH THE CURRENT DATA WE HAVE ON BAT SPECIES AND ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND WILL ASSIST IN DISPELLING NEGATIVE MYTHS AND STEREOTYPES ABOUT BATS  PROPOSED SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ANALYSIS OF STATIONARY ACOUSTIC DATA COLLECTED WITHIN BARNM AS PART OF PROPOSED ACTIVITIES, AS WELL AS OUTREACH EFFORTS ON BEHALF OF ENLC

SAGEBRUSH RESTORED AND RESPONSE OF THE GREATER SAGE GROUSE  REMOVAL OF  LOW DENSITY CONIFERS AWAY FROM MATURE PINON JUNIPER WOODLANDS IS THOUGHT TO MAXIMIZE BENEFIT  TO PRIORITY SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE SPECIES, THOUGH THE RESPONSE OF PINYON JAYS, WHICH ARE BOTH SAGE  AND WOODLAND DEPENDENT, TO CONIFER MANAGEMENT IS POORLY KNOWN  SPECIFICALLY, BECAUSE PINYON  JAYS USE BOTH WOODLAND AND SAGEBRUSH UNITS HAS ONLY JUST BECOME SMALL AND LIGHT ENOUGH TO BE ECONOMICALLY DEPLOYED ON PINYON JAYS   USING THESE NEW TOOLS TO COLLECT DETAILED LOCATION AND MOVEMENT DATA CREATES OPPORTUNITIES TO  ENSURE THEY ARE COMMONLY FOUND FORAGING AND CACHING IN PURE SAGEBRUSH A FEW  MILES FROM PINON JUNIPER WOODLANDS  AND THE SAGEBRUSH WOODLAND ECOTONE, WE WILL GAIN  SIGNIFICANT INFORMATION ON HABITAT USE AND TAGS  COLLECTIVELY, THESE DATA WILL GREATLY  ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF JAY HABITAT USE  THESE DATA WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANT  INFORMATION FOR FUTURE UPDATING OF THE PINYON JAY PREDICTIVE THE POTENTIAL FOR MEANINGFUL CONSERVATION ABOUND IN THE SAGEBRUSH STEPPE AND RECENT SCIENTIFIC  REPORTS HAVE CALLED ATTENTION TO THE NEED FOR ACTION. LAND AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS HAVE  INCREASINGLY RECOGNIZED THE IMPORTANT ROLE THAT EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION PLAYS IN THE OVERALL  SUCCESS OF MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. HOWEVER, THE LARGE GEOGRAPHY, WIDE RANGE OF SERVICES THAT ARE  OF INTEREST TO STAKEHOLDERS, CULTURAL DIFFERENCES, AND DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES MAKE COMMUNICATION  CHALLENGING. FURTHERMORE, PROFESSIONAL COMMUNICATORS ARE GENERALLY ISOLATED FROM PEERS IN  OTHER AGENCIES/ORGANIZATIONS, COMMUNICATION TOOLS ARE RAPIDLY EVOLVING, NEW SCIENCE AND  REPORTS ARE BEING RELEASED THAT ARE INFLUENCING THE MANAGEMENT OF SAGEBRUSH COUNTRY, AND A  BROADER SUITE OF NON-COMMUNICATION PROFESSIONALS ARE HAVING TO ENGAGE WITH THE PUBLIC WITHOUT  PROPER TRAINING. FUNDING IS BEING SOUGHT TO SUPPORT CONTINUATION OF A CREDIBLE AND IMPORTANT NETWORK,  SAGEWEST. THIS NONPARTISAN COMMUNICATION PLATFORM FACILITATES COLLABORATION AMONGST THE  VARIED ENTITIES ENGAGED IN MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM.  BY BRINGING TOGETHER VARIOUS ISSUE EXPERTS FROM DIVERSE SECTORS, TIMELY RESOURCES AROUND  EMERGING TOPICS AND RESOURCES/PRODUCTS ARE BROADLY ELEVATED AND TRAININGS/OUTREACH PRODUCTS  ARE CREATED TO ADVANCE COLLECTIVE AWARENESS AROUND IMPORTANT CONSERVATION CHALLENGES.  COMMUNICATION, OUTREACH, AND ENGAGEMENT ARE CRUCIAL COMPONENTS OF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL  RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATIONS NOT ONLY IMPROVE CURRENT MANAGEMENT  OUTCOMES BUT ALSO BUILD THE NEXT GENERATION OF MANAGERS, PRACTITIONERS, SCIENTISTS, AND  COMMUNICATORS WHO WILL HELP DETERMINE THE FUTURE OF THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM AND STIMULATE  OR SUSTAIN PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION ISSUES. WITH 45 PERCENT OF THE  SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM MANAGED BY THE BLM, PUBLIC SUPPORT AND ENGAGED STAKEHOLDERS ARE  ESSENTIAL TO ENSURE A SUSTAINABLE FUTURE FOR THIS ECOSYSTEM

WARNER WETLANDS IS A LARGE INTER-CONNECTED CHAIN OF LAKES AND WETLANDS THAT PROVIDES HABITAT FOR HUNDREDS OF SPECIES OF BIRDS IN SOUTHEAST OREGON. BLM HAS DESIGNATED WARNER WETLANDS AN AREA OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN AND A SPECIAL RECREATION MANAGEMENT AREA; THE WARNER BASIN HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED BY THE STATE OF OREGON AND THE NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY AS AN IMPORTANT BIRD AREA; AND THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HAS DESIGNATED THE WARNER BASIN WETLAND SYSTEM AS A CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREA. BLM HAS IDENTIFIED 11 SENSITIVE BIRD SPECIES THAT ARE KNOWN TO USE THE AREA OR HAVE BEEN DOCUMENT NEARBY: AMERICAN WHITE PELICAN, BALD EAGLE, BOBOLINK, BUFFLEHEAD, FRANKLIN'S GULL, HORNED GREBE, RED-NECKED GREBE, SNOWY EGRET, TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD, TRUMPETER SWAN, AND YELLOW RAIL. IN ADDITION, THE STATE OF OREGON CONSIDERS LONG-BILLED CURLEW, SANDHILL CRANE, AND SHORT-EARED OWL MANAGEMENT SENSITIVE SPECIES.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE PRONGHORN PASSAGE BY RETROFITTING BARBED WIRE FENCE TO WILDLIFE FRIENDLY STANDARDS OR REMOVING OBSOLETE FENCE IN MAPPED PRONGHORN HABITAT IN THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT LAKEVIEW DISTRICT. BARBED WIRE FENCES PRESENT THROUGHOUT THE LAKEVIEW DISTRICT POSE IMMEDIATE RISKS TO SEVERAL WILDLIFE SPECIES. PRONGHORN AND OTHER UNGULATES MAY BE UNABLE TO CROSS FENCE, LIMITING BOTH THEIR DAILY MOVEMENT AND SEASONAL MIGRATIONS, WHILE LOW-FLYING SAGE GROUSE ARE KNOWN TO BECOME ENTANGLED IN STANDING FENCE. THROUGH THE FENCE MAPPING PORTION OF THIS PROJECT WE WILL HELP BLM INVENTORY THE CONDITION OF FENCES IN MAPPED PRONGHORN HABITAT AND WORK WITH LAKEVIEW DISTRICT STAFF TO PRIORITIZE SECTIONS OF FENCE FOR FUTURE MODIFICATION AND IDENTIFY SECTIONS FOR POTENTIAL REMOVAL. FENCES THAT STILL SERVE A FUNCTIONAL PURPOSE TO CONTAIN LIVESTOCK DURING THE GRAZING SEASON CAN BE RETROFITTED TO MITIGATE SOME OF THE HAZARDS THEY POSE TO WILDLIFE.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT THE PARTNERS IN FLIGHT STRATEGY. THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE PRODUCTS THAT MEET THE DOI SECRETARY'S PRIORITIES TO ''CREATE A CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP LEGACY SECOND ONLY TO TEDDY ROOSEVELT'' AND MEET THE BLM'S PRIORITY OBJECTIVES BY WORKING WITH PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND INCORPORATE THE BEST WILDLIFE INFORMATION INTO MANAGEMENT DECISION AS WELL AS PROVIDING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES

LONG-TERM LANDBIRD MONITORING AT TWO STATIONS ON LANDS ADMINISTERED BY THE BLM IN WESTERN OREGON. THE RESULTS DIRECTLY PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT AVIAN COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND LONG-TERM POPULATION TRENDS OF INDIVIDUAL SPECIES THAT MEETS BLM'S FLPMA WILDLIFE GOALS OF INVENTORYING AND MONITORING WILDLIFE SPECIES AND HABITATS AND MAINTAINING DATA ON THESE EFFORTS TO INFORM LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THIS IS AN ONGOING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN BLM, KLAMATH BIRD OBSERVATORY, AND MULTIPLE PARTNERS AT A NATIONAL NETWORK TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE LONG-TERM LANDBIRD DATA EACH YEAR THAT IS ESSENTIAL FOR MAINTAINING HEALTHY LANDSCAPES FOR WILDLIFE AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES (BIRD HUNTING AND BIRD WATCHING).

UNDER THE GOOD NEIGHBOR AUTHORITY, FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ELIGIBILITY IS LIMITED TO A STATE. IN ACCORDANCE WITH COLLABORATIVE DIRECTION STEMMING FROM SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362, THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE WILL DETERMINE MOVEMENTS OF PRONGHORN THROUGHOUT BLM LANDS IN SOUTHEASTERN OREGON.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE PROTECTION OR RESOURCE OBJECTS OF IMPORTANCE AS OUTLINED BY THE MONUMENT PROCLAMATION. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP LEGACY BY ASSESSING THE POPULATION TRENDS OF THE ENDANGERED VESPER SPARROW IN THE MONUMENT, SO THAT MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND FUTURE HABITAT RESTORATION NEEDS CAN BE BASED ON KNOWN TRENDS AND CONDITION ASSESSMENTS.
